title: CLaMP 3: Universal Music Information Retrieval Across Unaligned Modalities and Unseen Languages
author: Shangda Wu (Central Conservatory of Music), Zhancheng Guo (Central Conservatory of Music), Ruibin Yuan (Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Junyan Jiang (New York University Shanghai), Seungheon Doh (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology), Gus Xia (Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence), Juhan Nam (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology), Xiaobing Li (Central Conservatory of Music), Feng Yu (Central Conservatory of Music), Maosong Sun (Tsinghua University)
relevance_why: The framework and methodologies presented in CLaMP 3, especially regarding retrieval-augmented generation, could improve the dataset curation process for audio-language tasks in Haohe's research.
background: The task setting involves developing a framework that retrieves musical content across various formats like sheet music, audio, and performance signals using textual descriptions, ideally across different languages.
contribution: This paper introduces CLaMP 3 to solve challenges related to music information retrieval across different modalities and languages, achieving state-of-the-art performance.
technical_comparison: Previous methods typically focused on specific modality pairs, limiting retrieval capabilities. This work improves by employing a unified framework utilizing contrastive learning and multilingual text encoding, enabling retrieval across unaligned modalities and unseen languages.
key_innovation: The integration of various musical modalities and a multilingual approach in a shared representation space allows for cross-modal retrieval without needing aligned training data.
real_world_impact: CLaMP 3 has the potential to revolutionize how users access and discover music across different cultures and formats, enhancing global music accessibility.
limitations: The paper mentions challenges in capturing temporal dynamics in music and the dependence on translation quality for multilingual retrieval evaluations.

new_terms.contrastive learning: **Contrastive learning** is a technique in machine learning where the model is trained to differentiate between similar and dissimilar examples, enhancing its ability to learn useful representations.
new_terms.retrieval-augmented generation: **Retrieval-augmented generation** refers to a framework that enhances text generation tasks by incorporating relevant information retrieved from external sources.

open_sourcing: The complete codebase and pre-trained weights of CLaMP 3 are available at https://github.com/sanderwood/clamp3
